section.title: Drawing Basics
section.para: A 'drawing' is a graphical visualization of a concept.

For some drawings, the nature of the concept can be left undefined, for example for artistic paintings. For other drawings, the nature of the concept is explicitly defined, for example for a UML class diagram.

We assume that a concept can be decomposed into smaller sub-concepts, which can in turn be decomposed into smaller sub-concepts until we reach a level of detail, where decomposition is no longer worthwhile.
We call the visual representation of (sub-)concept a 'figure'.
A drawing consists of a rectangular area: the drawing area.
The drawing holds a stack of layers.
A 'layer' is composed of figures.
A 'figure' is a visual representation of an element of a concept.
Some figures can be composed of other figures.
Some drawings can be used as a figure in other drawings.
